summary: In the 1950s, truck driver Frank Sheeran gets involved with Russell Bufalino and his Pennsylvania crime family. As Sheeran climbs the ranks to become a top hit man, he also goes to work for Jimmy Hoffa -- a powerful Teamster tied to organized crime.

reviews.content: Martin Scorsese does it again.
Scorsese, Pacino & De Niro what more could you ask for.

This movie is a complete disaster, long, boring, messed up plot, boring actors. You see these actors and you're like, oh that guy, who is he again? What year is it? What's going on? Wait I don't even care. Why was Joe P. made into a soft spoken boring guy? Every other film he was irate which is what he's good at, so frustrating. Everyone in the movie was just too old, boring, soft spoken. The film doesn't work because they're trying to cram the history of the mafia into a 3 1/2 hour time limit, so what you get is a jumbled mess. Big mistake was having all these 80 year old famous actors. They should've had younger ones play them in earlier scenes. Wow how ridiculous was that seeing a guy whose like 75 play a 30 year old, good lord.
Outstanding, nothing else to really say. Run time is indeed too long, but it's streaming so that's not a major downside.

when Frank said "I'm sitting there", I knew shit was gonna go down and it's gonna break my poor little soul. and on rewatch, it just gets worse. it is at this moment you realise why Frank insists on sitting in the backseat of the car when he, Sally and Chuck are going to pick up Jimmy to "straighten things out". it is at this moment that is so crucial in understanding the exact level of humanity that frank has.

I think this 3.5 hour film feels more like a 3 hour film because of the legendary presence of the big three Al Pacino, Robert DeNiro and Joe Pesci all paired up with the living legend Martin Scorsese. I probably haven't seen a 3.5 hour film (though they are few in numbers) move as fast as this one does just because it's so riveting. the story of Jimmy Hoffa is provided to the audience with such meticulous craft that I basically was in the world created by Marty for almost the enitrety of the runtime. it was also so refreshing to see actors of such huge calibre be back in their A-game after so long because DeNiro has been in some really crappy movies as of lately (most of them being comedies) and Pesci is basically retired at this point.

as for the performances, DeNiro is the best he's ever been and Al Pacino is just what I wanted him to be. he screams, he slams his hands on the table, he points towards everyone in the room and says his dialogues with a sense of sarcasm in them. he might come off as over the top to some people but for me, it's the kind of over the top that I love him for. Joe Pesci, on the other hand, is the real show-stealer for me. he is fucking cold. he is the kinda guy who, if double-crossed, would kill you and your entire lineage and wouldn't blink an eye. in fact, he would eat dinner after that, take a shower and go to bed. he is that cold. I loved his performance the most.

my favourite thing about this film though, is the occasional, trademark, scorsese's bloody violence each of which is set up perfectly through long drawn out sequences and just, pay off so well. one other thing is the final shot of the film. it reminds of Scorsese's past work The Departed, whose final frame was just perfect to look at. similar to that, this film also has a perfect final shot which is emotional and at times, terrifying to look at.

one thing that bugs me personally though, is that, I can't really recommend this film to anyone because this film isn't really made for everyone. I have a personal bias towards scorsese as a director and these actors in general. but believe me, when I write this review, I tried my best to avoid those biases getting in the way of the review, but even without those biases, this film is hard to recommend to somebody. people might find a 20 min long sequence of build-up meaningless and a waste of time which I found riveting and some of the best build-ups I've seen in a long time and they might think this film is just pretending to be genius.

anyways, I'd still recommend you see it. it's a legitimate piece of art.

Aside from a nostalgic and impressive cast and director in the same genre, this movie is pretty bland and boring.  We missed those characters and we got them back in this movie. The vehicle was marginal.

Too long, and dragged out. The Irishman was a disappointment. The acting was great, but the story was too slow and didn't keep my attention. The direction and cinematography were also lacking, and the editing was choppy. This movie could have been much better had it been edited down to a more manageable length.

Flashes of Scorsese magic only occasionally illuminate The Irishman. De Niro's lead character rarely provokes interest or sympathy while Pacino's shouty turn as Hoffa is over familiar. Joe Pesci does post a great performance but his quiet pathos is not enough to sustain the too long running time. Stephen Graham's dynamic appearances briefly evoke Scorsese's past glories but its soon back to the laboured script and superfluous characters. If Goodfellas was a 10 and Casino a 7, this is a 5 at best.

One needs little patience to watch this epic drama. Slowly slowly one gets addicted to its dialogues and the variety of pitch characters offer you. It is not a typical crime movie but a blend of comedy and tragedy. The central denouement comes when Frank decides to follow up with Russ and arguably he had all the good reasons for it. The ending shows us some meditations on life, sin and guilt to bring in the argument that beneath the facade of power lies the memory of the cross.

2 years ago- While the film is filled with good acting, strong direction, and intensely well done bursts of action, Scorsese remains at the top of his game in this greatest epic, even if it's pacing pales in comparison to some of the director's other efforts in terms of pacing.

While certainly a minor entry in Scorsese's filmography--it is overlong and unoriginal--fans of his work will likely enjoy it (especially the Academy). The Irishman is unlikely to entice newcomers to Scorsese's work, however, and it doesn't even rank among his top five films (despite its flaws, I would recommend Casino over this one).

I have to say that I found the movie to be rather boring and unnecessarily long.

The pacing of the film was slow, with long stretches of dialogue and little action. While the film's themes of loyalty, betrayal, and mortality were interesting, they were often buried beneath the excessive length of the movie. In fact, I found myself checking my watch multiple times throughout the film, waiting for it to be over.

Furthermore, the use of de-aging technology on the actors was distracting at times and did not always look convincing. While the film's technical aspects were impressive, they were not enough to make up for the lack of excitement in the plot.

a pretty damn good and compelling interpretation of mob violence in the 50s and 60s. the irishman is an amazing emotional rollercoaster of a film that chronicles the life of frank sheeran from a lowly and humble delivery driver for a deli all the way to a celebrated member of a crime family. robert de niro's depiction of frank is deeply complex, and, despite having quite a few iconic and admittedly even humorous "de niroisms," is able to exhibit a slew of emotions, showing how complicated of a man the real sheeran was. showing sheeran's doubts and complicated relationship with his crime family shows us a deeply troubled family man who is purely doing this as a result of bad connections and a dedication to his family, as seen through his unwillingness to kill jimmy hoffa, and his desperate attempt to remedy the situation between hoffa and the mob. the interpretation of sheeran and his possible involvement in hoffa's assassination is also incredibly interesting, framing him as the culprit. the film is also filled with sly humor, sarcasm, and quick violent cuts often synonymous with these kinds of mob movies. it's good fun at times, but also incredibly complex and emotional. it's a wild ride and a must watch mob movie with incredible acting by rob de niro and joe pesci

This is another Martin Scorsese epic, pulled off with the same energy and majesty of Wolf Of Wallstreet. This is the pinnacle crime/mob movie, as you truly follow every aspect of these characters, and with each passing minute you lose yourself in the film to a point where the characters are no longer characters but living breathing people who you really feel like you are following around through their shady and gruesome journey through the inner workings of their crime family syndicate. Scorsese nails it here, along with the amazing cast of legends like Al Pacino, Joe Pesci, Robert Deniro, and many others who lend their talents to this incredible story. If you haven't yet find the time to sit down and watch this must see epic, you won't be disappointed! I give The Irishman a 10/10.

Unsurprisingly, given its cast, director, and pedigree, The Irishman is vastly overrated. Which is not to say it's a bad movie - I don't think that would even be possible, with the players involved. But it's a plodding, hazy, thinner-than-it-looks affair, and though its dull pace and meandering plot is meant to be the point - this is the rumination of a man at the end of his long life - that doesn't save it from what it is. 

As a character study, it's interesting in places. Frank is a chillingly blank soldier whose eventual grief at the one job he never wanted to do is marked in its uniqueness, and De Niro plays him well, Joe Pesci has more to latch onto with his soft-spoken boss, Russell. and Pacino is his Pacino-est as an explosive Jimmy Hoffa. Speaking of whom, it's in conveying the history that features prominently throughout the story where comes up shortest. Covering decades of tumultuous goings-on, perhaps it bit off more than it could chew, because the brush strokes are too airy; we get no real sense of the weight of these events.

Granted, this is in parts by design. Frank and Russell are largely untouched by these momentous events, though Hoffa, being a real historical person, is deeply entwined. Yet we never really get a sense of the man's importance. His rock-star status in the Teamsters is conveyed largely by reaction shots at rallies, but you never get much to explain why these people love him. Tough luck if you don't already know; The Irishman is not here to teach you.

This has been mentioned in other reviews, of course, but it bears repeating: The Irishman also has a woman problem. It bears repeating, because it takes a woman to complete one of the film's most poignant and necessary scenes, wherein one of Frank's daughters takes him to task for his ways. In a quiet, tearful, tragic manner, she explains to Frank the devastating effect his violent life and thoughtless behavior has had on his own family. Not even Harvey Keitel's Angelo Bruno corners Frank so well, in the scene where Frank discovers he bombed the wrong place. For his transgression against Bruno, Frank is forgiven. For terrorizing his daughters, it's much too late, even if Frank could bring himself to regret anything he's done. It's a great scene in a film well-stocked with them, but unfortunately, they don't add up to a great movie.

Based on the book "I heard you paint houses'', The irishman examines american corruption from the point of view of one of its invisible architects. An extraordinarily powerful film that starts with a single man and pulls back to expose the country that for better—and especially worse—he helped make, The Irishman offers another vivid, indelible portrait of humanity from a filmmaker who realizes there's less time in front of him than behind, and possesses enough wisdom and skill to look back on where he's been—and where we've been—while forging ahead with a style and creativity that feels invigorating, vital and timeless.

The Irishman is work of art made by Scorsese. Each and every scene is significant and contributes to the movie as a whole. Robert De Niro, Al Pacino and Joe Pesci did an excellent job especially Pesci. Even Stephen Graham did an amazing job of playing

And by a very large margin at that. Because given some of the absolute classics that he has helped to make, then to say that this is worse does little to explain the gulping chasm there is between most of his work, and this utter dreck.

Didn't make it through the film, and nothing about the plot, acting, or cinematography makes me want to try to finish it. Boring and predictable violence, with no interesting characters. 

If Scorsese truly wants to challenge himself, he should try to make his next film an outright dark comedy, since he was the only one smart enough to take Jerry Lewis on as a serious dramatic talent so many years ago. The Irishman - 9.5/10. Martin Scorsese has had a masterful and incredible filmography. The Irishman (or I Heard You Paint Houses), is a 3.5 hour epic. Before I get into the review, I would say the only reason why I didn't give it a full 10 is because it feels a little longer than needed. Other than that, this film is a journey that you need to watch. Like Goodfellas and Casino, Scorsese dives into the crime world, and shows the life of a man who is within it. Robert Deniro, Al Pacino, and Joe Pesci deliver some of their best performances of their career's. Each person lives through their characters, and we get to see some real fleshed out character arcs through the run time. The movie follows a hitman who starts from humble beginnings as a hardworking driver to becoming a main cog in the gang underworld. Unlike some of his earlier work, Scorsese doesn't try to speed up the proceedings with quick cuts or fast camera movements. This film is a definite slowburn, and it might feel like a long watch for some. But if you're a cinematic like me, it feels like a gift from the director. He wants you to be immersed in the story, and take the journey with Deniro's character. The character recounts his life and you get to see how real life events and people affect his livelihood and way of business. One great thing about the film is that it never overreacts or becomes melodramatic. Characters flaring up or going into tension don't automatically start yelling matches or fist fights. The conflicts are show realistically. We get some great writing from Steve Zallian and amazing all around performances from the cast, especially some subtle performances from Ray Romano and Anna Paquin. The set designs transport you to those times, while the CGI that people were worried about doesn't seem that distracting at all. All in all, a really great film. Maybe not one of Scorsese's all time bests, but it holds up there! Go watch it now on Netflix!

So much is wrong with this movie.

First and foremost--the actors Pesci, DeNiro, and Pacino are asked to play, for long stretches, roles for men 4,3, or 2 decades younger than they are.  For a brief moment, it can work.  But for long stretches, it just looks, sounds, and feels...FAKE. Dumb.  Imagine if Coppola, making Godfather II, had cast Brando as both the old Godfather and the young.  It would have been almost as bad as this (Brando was younger then than DeNiro is now).  Instead, Coppola made an epic great pic by casting DeNiro as the young Godfather.  Maybe Scorcese is so old now that he doesn't see how terrible this one decision made his movie.  But it just sucked so bad because of that.

Still, if the script had been better, it would have worked.  But there is almost NOTHING to pull you into this movie. Unlike, say, Casino or Goodfellas or the Departed, there is no compelling vivid character or scene.  Everything just reminds you of death, aging and dying.  There are also no female characters who get anything like a developed character to play.  They barely have any lines.

The script also just meanders...Allegedly, it is supposed to be building to the death of Hoffa.  But it's like bad Shakespeare.  We all see it coming, and yet we have to have a boring game of telephone, where Russ (Pesci) tells Frank (DeNiro) to tell Hoffa (Pacino) to give in to the mob, Hoffa says no, that message goes back, Frank carries back their reply....on and on and over and over and it's truly that dumb and that visually boring.  

This was almost unwatchable.  It's so bad that it makes you question whether the director still has anything left to say via cinema.

What's truly tragic is that, if you had given DeNiro, Pesci, and Pacino age appropriate parts throughout, you might have had a great movie. You'd have to bring in talented actors to play the young parts....but the movie gets a LITTLE better in the last 25 minutes because DeNiro and Pesci are playing characters right around their correct ages, and when that awful fakeness fades off the screen, you see the real talent being wasted, not just the talent of the actors but the director's own still powerful visual sense. The scene where an aging DeNiro falls in his hallway is lit so originally, so beautifully...

But overall--boring, bad, avoid.

That said, Scorsese and his old pals clearly have a hoot re-enacting their youth, and the charisma leaps from screen undiminished even by Pacino's hammish scene-stealing. The story is a corker, interwoven with the biggest events of mid-twentieth century Americana, and with a beautiful score and lovely touches (like freeze-frame captions that tell you the death-by-date of every real-life mobster that makes an appearance - very handy for Wikipedia checks) that pull it along with all the panache you'd expect from Scorsese. Frank Sheeran (Robert DeNiro) is a hitman entirely driven by his fear of something harsher than death: finality. If there's any truth to religion, death is less an end, more a transition, but finality is an unalterable blackness to which no consciousness will wake from. Of course, death is it's closest relation, and Frank is exposed to a world where death is at the forefront of his reality – it's real to him in a way it's not to you and I, and he can only carry the attitude as long as it's not me to survive. He probably developed this in World War II, where death was first nature. His killing of two unarmed Nazis, digging their own grave, will be the most buildup we get for any of his kills. In Frank's eyes, this is a story about survival. But for us, it's a story about stories. These are the kinds of stories we tell when we're scrambling to make meaning of life with the looming shadow of death approaching.

Many have widely misinterpreted that this is a film about the events leading up to Jimmy Hoffa's death, but it's not a film about the real Hoffa at all. If anything, it's Hoffa in a dream, filtered through the memory of blood-stained Frank, who knew him well enough to tell tales. It's a story of probability; some things happened, some things didn't, and much was embellished. But aren't stories always embellished? Which is why this film deals with aging, the most natural cause to search for meaning in life. Stories are the spiritual makeup of humanity. Irishman is completely existential in this sense, a kind of primitive art, resembling the core purpose of our ancestors' spiritual mythology. Scorsese has tapped into this deep level of dreaming a movie, the way our early mythmakers saw their worlds and characters come alive, never unrelated to the real world around them. It is a reflection of Frank himself, actually giving his life meaning through telling these stories, whether they're true, untrue, or somewhere in between.

The film takes place through three timelines: the present, Frank in a nursing home telling his stories; the beginning, Frank's journey from joining the mob through befriending Jimmy Hoffa (Al Pacino); and the middle, Frank and Russ Bufalino (Joe Pesci) on their way to a wedding, with something much more sinister in the works. Frank started out as a truck driver delivering meat, a brother in Hoffa's union, when fate led him to meeting Russ, the kind of guy who sits next to mob bosses like Angelo Bruno (Harvey Keitel). Frank has a sweetness about him, seems like a harmless guy – of course he does, this is how he has to remember himself - but for whatever reason he finds himself getting involved in the mob's activities. He's not a particularly ambitious Sam Rothstein (Casino), he didn't want to carve out his life this way like Henry Hill (GoodFellas), and he's not psychotic like Johnny Boy (Mean Streets). Frank is the most mysteriously motivated of all Scorsese gangsters, but circumstances reveal it's always survival [from finality]. At one point, he gets in trouble for blowing up territory part owned by Angelo, though completely ignorant of this. He alludes to having a new child and needing more money as his reason for doing it. And while he should be whacked, Angelo pardons him because Russ vouches for him, just one in a series of events that forge Frank's deepest loyalty to Russ. When he handles things for Russ, it's out of respect, not money.

Russ eventually assigns Frank to be the right-hand man of Hoffa, the union president, and Frank is more than willing to oblige. Frank may not be hungry for power, but he's very appreciative of moving up the ladder. At first, Hoffa just needs some help with rivals, but the problems grow much more complex as he encounters friction within the union, and the mob that's helping him. Frank has venerable memories of Hoffa; a montage of his "bigger than Elvis" influence over minions, juxtaposed with sleeping in the same room as him. Their bond grows quickly and personally, developing familial relations. Hoffa's the first of Frank's friends that his standoffish daughter Peggy (Lucy Gallina) is accepting of, as she knows Russ and the rest are gangsters. There's another poignant montage intercutting Peggy's proud school presentation on Hoffa, stating all his idealisms, with the reality of his hypocrisy; building pension fund for workers, but giving it away in loans to the mob. This is no secret to attorney general Robert F. Kennedy (Jack Huston), who interrogates Hoffa about his shady dealings. We know that Hoffa is bound for prison, and this will be a turning point for him, but the question of loyalty will remain: who is, and who isn't?

There's an invisible food chain, a hierarchy that stretches into the darkness, which we can never fully fathom, but which we hear about. Hoffa still feels like he's in control from behind bars, his puppet Fitz (Gary Basaraba) running orders. But Hoffa slowly begins to find his place on the food chain, and soon, Fitz is responding to orders from elsewhere. A growing union leader, Tony Pro (Stephen Graham), poses a new threat for Hoffa's leadership, despite joining him in prison. They both know they'll be out eventually, and when they are, things will be different. Hoffa's ego can't deal with the power status changing around him, refusing to see the mob taking control of the union, clinging on to his only belief, "this is my union." The more he fights back, the more the mob doesn't like it. And that's when talk begins about the fate of Jimmy Hoffa. Frank is stuck in the middle, his loyalty at stake between his friend and the people who take care of him.

Every characteristic highlighted is a function of Frank's memory, which fondly recalls Hoffa. Frank may be a hardened killer, unable to feel remorse for his crimes, but he has a soft spot for Hoffa. He remembers him eating ice cream a lot, the chat they shared by their beds in pajamas like boys at a sleepover, and the times he danced with Peggy. Experiencing the fate of Hoffa is heart wrenching, and yet another tale entered into the mythos of his mysterious disappearance. Just the same, there's warmth for Russ, the man who practically crowned an Irishman a made guy in the Italian mob. They were friends until the end. The third act deals with Frank and Russ, geriatrics now, rotting in prison. Watching Frank's senior obstacles pile on, regressing to a helpless state, is the poignancy of a six-film arc; through all the power achieved by illegitimate means, you could never escape the four sufferings of birth, aging, sickness, and death.

Scorsese has changed his form, evolving his cinematic style to complement what is likely the last chapter in his gangster saga. It's a shame for anyone to see this without experiencing the full six movements. What it means thematically to his body of work is as important as a chapter is to a book, part of a greater whole. But as with each installment, it never treats itself as a puzzle piece, it is a whole entity unto itself. Mean Streets appropriately began the story with its namesake, the street-level cronies. GoodFellas explored the mid-level mob, while Casino showed the mob with it's own city at the top-level. Gangs of New York brought us back to the 1800s and showed us the historical roots of the mob. And his Oscar-winning The Departed flipped sides to see it from the law enforcement perspective. They've been caught, and now the only thing they can do is rot. That's what The Irishman is; it behaves this way, as age and decline do. Gone is the frenetic pacing, fast editing, and flashy lights of previous installments. The Irishman is finality; the end of an era not just for the mob, but for Scorsese and his crew in this genre. The mastery is in how the film behaves: slow, patient, subdued, clinging to memories; a reflection of the mob's glory days waning. Lower-thirds reveal details about characters we don't get to intimately know, telling us when they died and how – Scorsese isn't spending his time creating the illusion of glorification anymore. This is the life: death!
Unlike the unreliable narrator in Henry Hill, whose telling of the lifestyle is contradicted by outcomes, Frank seems honest, but this is only because his unreliability is more complicated, and requires breaking the fourth wall into the real world, where it's been suggested that his confessions are largely embellished. The most important, talked about technique is the use of digital de-aging. Different televisions will have a different effect, but on mine, the image is completely photorealistic. But I also say that if it isn't for you, it doesn't have to be. A slight surreal quality may even be intended; this is an old man trying to remember himself and key players when they were younger, and any imperfections are in him trying to imagine it.
Life has to mean something. Whether it's picking a green casket over a black one, or a .32 over a .22 caliber gun, the accumulation of all our choices form the unique matrix that tell our story, which is our spiritual energy field. Scorsese, at 77 years old, is right to choose this point in his life to express that. The way Frank prepares for his death may seem hapless and cold, but that's the comeuppance of a man who killed in cold blood, scared his family away, and was drawn into betrayal. Now he's that old man desperate to tell his stories to anyone who will listen. Are we just a bunch of suckers? Probably. We're the last thing Frank needs – we're sitting on the other side of that fourth wall looking at him, and he's looking right back at us. The last thing he asks for is to keep his door slightly open. It's like if you shut the door, you throw up a border between life and death, and in it he's isolated. The open door creates the illusion that he's still connected to that world out there, that he somehow matters. This is not unlike the Day of the Dead ritual, in which preserving the memory of loved ones keeps them alive in the afterlife, helping them along their spiritual journey. Frank seeks remembrance through us. His ultimate act will be ‘confession,' another ritual preparing the soul for its journey. Whether the illusion is finality itself, or escaping it, will be for Frank to find out.

Crime epic that represents a return to form by all involved.  Robert De Niro gives one his best lead performances as Frank Sheeran, a World War II vet who slowly finds himself deep inside the Teamsters Union and the mob, with his story detailing how they became entangled, along with his friendship to Teamsters boss, Jimmy Hoffa (a excellent Al Pacino).  The real star is Joe Pesci as Russell Bufalino, the soft spoken mob boss who becomes Frank's friend and mentor.  Behind the camera, Martin Scorcese makes one of his best films in years, using the story of Sheeran's rise in the mob as a metaphor for greed and corruption, as they more successful Sheeran becomes, the emptier his soul gets (the final scene is devastating).  Whether he is telling the truth about what happened to Hoffa or not doesn't matter, as its more about the corruption a life of crime does to all people.  The one downside is the use of de-aging technology to depict the characters throughout the years, but that disappears after a few minutes, as the acting and storytelling takes over.  Even its three and a half length isn't imposing (especially if you stream it on Netflix), as this a a true epic, and well worth viewing.

It would be hard to find a film that had more coverage than Martin Scorsese's latest foray in gangster cinema. a genre that he has shown ''somewhat of an affinity with'' in the past, something that the Oscars have recognized with GOOD FELLAS, THE DEPARTED and GANGS OF NEW YORK.

Based on the confessions of mov hitman Frank Sheeran, aka ''The Irishman'', who formed a friendship with Union leader Jimmy Hoffa, who years later disappeared mysteriously.

Sporting an insanely good cast, with De Niro as Sheeran, Pacino as Hoffa, and Joe Pesci as mob boss Russell Bufalino. After the quick taste that Michael Mann's HEAT had provided in 1995, and the horrible RIGHTEOUS KILL in 2008, one could wonder if we would ever get to see De Niro and Pacino share the screen once again. Thanks to Netflix' deep pockets, Scorsese was able to assemble that dream cast and tackle this decades spanning saga.

THE IRISHMAN isn't as thorough as CASINO or GOOD FELLAS in demonstrating the inner workings of the mob and, in this case, its influence on the Unions run by Jimmy Hoffa. I learned more about that aspect in a 2006 special report featuring Sheeran's ''confession'' and comments from his lawyer and author of the book ''I Heard You Paint Houses: Frank "The Irishman" Sheeran & Closing the Case on Jimmy Hoffa''. It does have the advantage to be based on more recent findings on the case, making it more relevant than Danny De Vito's 1993 HOFFA with Nicholson in the lead.

I would have thought that at 209 minutes, it would have had the time to be a bit clearer on that aspect, but it seems Scorsese was more interested in exploring the characters and their relationships than the mechanics of mob-related shenanigans. And with actors like his leads, delving in character development is a gift.

In fact the biggest strength and the most obvious weakness of THE IRISHMAN resides in its leads. There is no denying that there is an undeniable pleasure from seeing them work together, and their friendship makes some scenes infinitely more heartbreaking. However, their age (76 for De Niro and 79 for Pacino) makes it difficult, even with the aid of computerized de-aging technology, to make it completely believable that they are, at certain points in the film, at least 30 years younger. Their stance and their overall energy belies their age. It's not a deal-breaker for me, but it made a full immersion in the film difficult.

While it doesn't have the vitality of some of his greatest work, feeling much like the film of an older, wiser man than the angry one who made TAXI DRIVER in 1976 or GOOD FELLAS in 1990, THE IRISHMAN remains an important film in Scorsese' career, A film that takes the time not only to explore the actions of its protagonists, but also to linger on the consequences of their actions on them, their family and their regrets.

Martin Scorsese teams up with Netflix to deliver the captivating crime drama The Irishman.  Based on a supposed "true crime" novel, the film follows a teamster named Frank Sheeran who becomes a mob enforcer and goes to work for Jimmy Hoffa.  Starring Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, Joe Pesci, and Harvey Keitel, the cast is especially strong and gives solid performances.  Additionally, the de-aging CGI is pretty effective, allowing the actors to play a variety of ages; though there are times where their movements betray their real ages.  The sets and costumes are also well-done, giving an authentic feel for the time-periods.  However, the film is about an hour too long; including a lot of unnecessary and superfluous scenes.  Yet despite a few weaknesses, The Irishman is a compelling film about the toll a life of crime takes.
No matter how long the time passes, Martin Scorsese will never lose his touch. It was also amazing to see Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, and Joe Pesci in a movie together with Martin Scorsese.

After originally disliking this movie, I read some of the reviews. Maybe I was missing something. Maybe everyone talking about the great acting were right. Maybe the story actually did have a discernible plot that revealed itself before 2/3 of the way through it. 
I did the unthinkable: I re-watched it. Yes, folks. I saw this movie twice so you wouldn't have to see it once. It is every bit as bad the second time.
1st is the de-aging process. If you're going to make someone look forty-five years younger then it's a good idea to also have them move like they're forty-five years younger. Here we see a 75 year old De Niro looking like a 30 year old. Yet when he starts beating on someone he moves like a 75 year old. If you're going to de-age someone then de-age their moves. Either that or get a younger actor. It is shameful that Scorsese would allow this to happen. Did they not see this in the cuts? Did it not occur to anyone that De Niro might not be able to beat someone up like he could in 1990? I thought Scorsese was a better filmmaker than this.
2nd is the run-time. The first half of the film drags on and on. We get it. He's a truck driver and then becomes a freelance mob enforcer. We didn't need an hour and a half to have that explained to us. We didn't need the story about the family, which is irrelevant even as a sub-plot to the main plot. 
3rd is the aforementioned plot. We don't have any idea what this movie is really about until Jimmy Hoffa finally appears what seems like six hours after the movie starts. Pacino does a good job. I only felt a slight amount of his usual "Hoo-Ah" acting style that he developed after Scarface and refined in Scent of a Woman. Maybe we could have had more Pacino and much, much less irrelevant backstory.
This movie may have been much better with a two hour runtime. The backstory alone was two hours long before the real plot developed. Through much of this movie I found myself saying, "who cares? Get on with it!" Another thing with a semi-historical drama is that we already know what happens. We don't need to dwell on topics which are common knowledge. It just prolongs an already long story. 
Scorsese hit it big with a few of his early movies and then really took off with Goodfellas, which for its time was groundbreaking. Since then he has muddled around, often using the same, tired formula. Casino was a way-too-long Goodfellas in Vegas attempt. Gangs of New York was redeemed by the brilliant acting of Daniel Day-Lewis. Otherwise it almost could have been a documentary. The Aviator had a chance to be brilliant, but Scorsese expects us to sit through hours of nothing happening. Only a maturing DiCaprio saved that from being a complete disaster. In 
The Departed he tried to get too clever. Jack Nicholson's over the top acting didn't help it much. With The Wolf of Wall Street we're brought back to that same Goodfellas formula, but with drugs and stock trading rather than gangsters. And now we get another Goodfellas formulaic movie which is probably the worst of the bunch.

As cinematic technology and filming methods progress, so does the art of storytelling. This is superbly manifested in Martin Scorsese's bold move by pushing his mob story past the three-hour mark through careful pacing and stellar cinematography. What would seem like a tedious viewing is quite the opposite, as The Irishman provides a gripping tale with likeable characters; personalities that viewers would not soon forget long after viewing this epic tale. Those familiar with Scorsese's method of storytelling and stylistic cues will feel right at home with The Irishman, as the film is arguably the perfect culmination of all that is great about Scorsese. Based on true events, the film follows Irish-American Frank Sheeran, an unassuming truck driver who rises up the ranks of Russel Bufalino's crime family, later becoming one of the top members. Whereas several past films on the subject glorify the mob life in some ways, The Irishman heads in the opposite direction, providing a dark and realistic tale about everyday life as a hitman, government corruption and involvement with crime families, and the intricate hierarchy that Mafia members adhere to. Few films commit such effort to push the audience to acquaint themselves with the characters and perceive the emotions conveyed. Such scenes where we get a glimpse into the thoughts of a man just before he takes a life, the petty rivalries between certain individuals that lead to bloodbaths, or scenes that portray just how unceremonious and brutal mob killings are, give viewers a fresh look at the realities of life in the Mafia and forces the audience to simmer in the dark, awkward atmospheres that the film creates so wonderfully; a goal many similar films fail to meet. Aided by brilliant costume design and a legendary cast, The Irishman is absolute essential viewing for Scorsese fans and is sure to please those craving a dark and immersive epic film noir that will more than likely be regarded as an American classic for decades to come.

It's not like we haven't seen this type of story told before but what 'The Irishman' is trying to say by the end of this sprawling mob epic is more profound than several of it's familiar plot developments and predicable bursts of violence. With its 3.5 hour length, Martin Scorsese's latest can be a gripping endeavor at times, chronicling the career of Frank Sheeran and his eventual downfall. I do appreciate that this is a quieter, more contemplative take on a mob story, one that lingers more in the moments with its characters as much as it details the intrigues of their organizations. Robert De Niro doesn't disappoint as "mostly" easy-going, loyal Frank Sheeran. Coming out of his retirement from acting, Joe Pesci gives a remarkable turn as Russell Bufalino. In contrast to his memorably bombastic performances in 'Goodfellas' & 'Casino', Pesci's Russell is disarmingly calm and focused. But there is a peculiar coldness about him and a sheltered rage hidden behind his eyes at times that makes you believe this guy will get shit done. Despite the skills of De Niro & Pesci, the chill nature of their characters and the deliberate pacing of the story can lull one to sleep if you're aren't prepared for it. Once Al Pacino comes into the picture, the movie picks up and Pacino is amazing as Jimmy Hoffa. He injects energy & warmth into the proceedings that's rather lacking otherwise; and his interplay with the rest of the cast is riveting. 

I have a couple issues with the movie but my main one is about the visual effects used to de-age the lead actors. To be clear, I think the VFX work here is solid & important. I was never drawn-out of the movie because the VFX looked fake. On the contrary, the VFX are nearly seamless. I was distracted by the fact that Robert De Niro & Joe Pesci don't look young enough to be in their 30s or early 40s. The effects on Pacino fair better (the acclaimed actor looking like he did in the late 90s). ‘The Irishman' might test the viewers patience, depending on their taste or alertness but it well worth a look for Scorsese's command of the production and the performances; closing out in a rather haunting, heartbreaking ending that shows the true consequences of unflinching loyal in a reprehensible line of work. 
– 8/10

"The Irishman" a contemplative and enriching 3-hour 30-minute crime saga that stars a trio of mob movie legends. The film marks Scorsese's return to the gangster milieu and his first collaboration with De Niro in decades. Yet the director does not merely rehash the genre, and instead remains as innovative and stimulating as he was in his heyday. 

Though "The Irishman" is very clearly a Scorsese film, it is not as manic as "Goodfellas" or opulent as "Casino." Not much screen time is devoted to Frank's bloody business. When Frank has to kill, it is swift and simplistic. It is not heavily glorified or stylized and instead comes off as shameful. The majority of the film's screen time is devoted to everyday Mafia conversation, although it is never mundane. 

The film's sprawling narrative flashes back to Frank and Russell's first meeting, and at times forward to the nursing home until these storylines converge. Traditional cinematic rules, such as flashbacks within flashbacks and conventional concepts of structure and pacing are ignored. But these various times and locations never become jumbled.

Even though The Irishman has an excessive runtime of 3h30 minutes, which some can find very hard to sit through, it's an interesting, and especially very well made gangster flick. It's a pleasant reminder of director Scorsese's earlier gangster movies like Mean Streets (1973), the Goodfellas (1990) and the terrific The Departed (2006). This film reunited the gangster legends of Al Pacino, Robert DeNiro and Joe Pesci, which just makes this crime epic better and more authentic. The cinematography is pretty beautiful, it's occasionally quite gory and the de-aging of the actors is actually pretty fancy. Overall, this is an ambitious, big budget project from a mastermind of filmmaking, and while some parts are indeed quite long, this is still an impressive gangster pic based on a true story. And it's a must see for any lover of the genre. Recommended!!

At the heart of it is Robert De Niro as Frank Sheeran, an Irishman, making meat deliveries and taking a cut for himself because he works hard and deserves it. But when we first meet him it's saggy-eyes and wispy white hair in a nursing home, wheelchair bound and sitting alone, recounting his story inside his head, contemplating the past. We're introduced to the narrative framing of the film which has Frank and mob boss Russell Bufalino (Pesci) going on a family road trip of sorts. The two are a delight here, their eyes glittery with decades of acting nuance. It's like they've never been away. It's a shame Pesci has retired, because he's incredible. His performance is as delicate and wise as his body, with a career-span of intelligence sparkling behind his cool blue eyes. The Oscars surely has his name ready. It's the type of performance that only he could give and could give at this age. It's made possible by state-of-the-art de-aging technology, which better allows Scorsese to explore the effect of looking into the past through the lens of the old and present. It's uncanny when we slip through De Niro's current eyes and into his new pair twenty or so years into the film's past. There's a hint of The Polar Express (2004) about it, but it's all so easily swept aside by De Niro's controlled, devastating performance and Scorsese's assured direction. After ten minutes I never noticed it again. I was in the grip of a master.

As it flits back and forth between the road trip and Frank's rise through the mob ranks, becoming not only Russell's most trusted client, but his closest friend, the film slowly explores the nature of time as an unstoppable force that is going to catch you one way or another. For the mobsters, if you're not shot on the job, it's prison, and if prison doesn't get you, the nursing home afterwards will. A pitch-black sense of humour flows through the whisky-shot wrinkled veins of The Irishman. Near the end, Frank is told his old attorney has died and that he can confess now because nobody is going to whack him. He asks the detectives, ‘Who did it?', as if expecting somebody he knows. They stare at him, dead serious, ‘Cancer.'

There was a time when all the men Frank knew couldn't be touched, and if you did, you were likely to be shot in the back of the head in your favourite restaurant with your children watching. But in the third act, and the time that Frank recounts his story, that's all gone. The violence, the glamour, the glory, all of it has given way to something more terrifying: time. Frank can only reflect on the past. Scorsese lets us experience it as Frank does, poignantly using technology to turn back the clock of these wonderful stars, letting us relive the gangster epics of old, conjuring up the magic of Goodfellas (1990) and Casino (1995), rocking to the woozy tunes of The Five Satins, but then it's over, and we're back in the nursing home, coming out of Frank's head, staring at nothing with nobody to hold. The film works as well as it does because of its aging stars and director, all of whom have contributed greatly to the crime epics of cinema, and it is fitting that they would all come together to tell a story about what happens when all of this fades like an old photograph. It's Scorsese's late-career masterpiece, and unbelievably, it is made possible by Netflix.

Pay attention to all the watches scattered about the film, they're not an accident. And it's not accident when Scorsese lingers on Frank's hand as he places a gun next to a ticking watch. Tick-tock, tick-tock. It means the gun is going to be used soon. But it has further implications by the end of the film. The gun is not the most efficient weapon. It's time. Time always catches up. You can't outrun it; you can only make the best of it. Unfortunately, as Frank falls deeper into the underbelly of America and entangles himself in the affairs of union leader Jimmy Hoffa (a funny and magnificent Al Pacino) he begins to lose sight of his daughter Peggy (later played by Anna Paquin), and quite literally, she drifts out of the film as she has drifted from his life. Paquin barely utters a word in the fragment of screen time that she has, but her presence and the impact it has on the film's closing stages is essential. For all its glamorised violence, and brilliant back and forth wise cracking between its trio of stars, the moments that stay with you are the ones of Frank navigating the lonely, troubling road of retirement. The Irishman is about the past catching up. It's about reflecting on what's lost as you face the final chime of the clocktower. It's achingly sad when Frank visits Peggy late in the film, struggling along on his walking stick, only for her to shut the window and walk away. Frank has lost his chance to rekindle his relationship with his daughter. He spent it all painting houses.

Things aren't stated directly in the mafia. They use codes and euphemisms but everyone involved understands clearly. So, when mob hitman Frank Sheeran is told by his boss and longtime friend, Russell Bufalino, "It's what it is" about Frank's other longtime friend and mentor, Jimmy Hoffa, his heart crumbles.  Those words signal a point of no return for everyone involved and set into motion the final hour of Martin Scorsese's I Heard You Paint Houses, or, The Irishman. It is also the most poignant and compelling hour of filmmaking of any film I saw from 2019. The proceeding two and a half hours, also excellently done, bring the total runtime to 3hours 29minutes. This is Scorsese's longest film, and, also, one of the best films in the career of one of, if not the, greatest living film directors.

We learn from an elderly Frank Sheeran (Robert De Niro), narrating his life story from a nursing home, that a "house painter" is mafia code for a hit man. De Niro's narration is quiet and full of reflection and regret. He isn't narrating so much as confessing. He tells an unseen listener about a road trip he and Russell Bufalino (Joe Pesci) took with their wives to attend a wedding, but the real reason for the road trip was "business." The story of the road trip acts a spring board to flashback to the 1950's when Frank went from a union truck driver looking to make extra money to a "house painter" to bodyguard and friend of Teamsters Union president, Jimmy Hoffa (Al Pacino).

The screenplay, adapted by Steve Zaillian from the book I Heard You Paint Houses by Charles Brandt, allows the characters to build their personalities and inner lives through small moments like conversations in cars or restaurants. The back and forth between the actors bring the characters and the movie to life. There are several scenes that are as tense as they are entertaining, especially Hoffa's meeting with a rival in the teamsters, who arrives late and wearing shorts. It's the kind of scene that Scorsese specializes in.

De Niro gives one of his best and most "Robert DeNiro" performances. Narration aside, he says as little as he can with as few words as he can, even then stammering over phrases. Emotion is just below the surface of a quiet, stony exterior. Joe Pesci comes out of retirement to give one of his best and most unexpected performances. Unlike the hot head tough guy characters he is most famous for, Pesci as Bufalino is a calm tough guy. He never has an outburst or raises his voice but his aura is no less intimidating. Here, Pesci tries to mediates potentially violent situations. He asks an agitated Hoffa if there's "another reason" for his actions in such a calm and inoffensive tone you get the feeling that Pesci's version of Bufalino would have been a good therapist or marriage counselor. Al Pacino is over the top as Jimmy Hoffa but his acting style works because the real-life Hoffa was an outspoken, flamboyant, larger than life personality (Jack Nicholson's performance as Hoffa in Danny DeVito's film, Hoffa, is among his most ostentatious). Harvey Keitel, who starred in Scorsese's first film has a small part as the mafia boss, Angelo Bruno. He sits like a king in his restaurant booth exuding a cool but threatening presence.

The digital de-aging of the actors to make them look up to 30 years younger than their actual ages works well enough; it helps that their ages are never specified. As an effect, the de-aging is far from convincing but not very distracting, except for one shot where young Joe Pesci's face appears to be floating over his body. The overall effect, however, is no different than dying their hair darker. However, the performances do feel richer for having the same actors in the same roles throughout the film.

Films like Mean Streets, Goodfellas, and Casino (featuring Harvey Keitel, Robert De Niro, and Joe Pesci) have made Scorsese synonymous with the modern gangster picture. Each of those films glamorized the criminal life to a certain extent to show its insidious appeal. There is not a bit of glamour to be found in The Irishman. There is no luxury or appeal to Frank's lifestyle. When not carrying out hits or driving a truck across the country, he acts as a go-between for Hoffa and the mob bosses trying to diffuse potentially dangerous situations.

The Irishman is an epic film. It sprawls not over picturesque landscapes but a life in crime. It feels episodic, any complete life story would, but it flows smoothly. The doo-wop song "In the Still of the Night" by The Five Satins opens the film and plays more like a dirge than a pop song. It sets the tone for the film perfectly. The brilliant score by Robbie Robertson feels like it grew out of the film's contemplative, somber tone. This story explores what it means to survive a life of crime and what it leaves a person with. Frank entered the criminal world to make more money to take care of his family, but there are tellingly few scenes of Frank with his family. What was it all for?

This is a long movie and it feels like a long movie—I won't argue that—but it is also thoroughly engrossing. I was completely immersed in these lives and this world without ever wanting to be a part of them. The first two-thirds of the film builds up emotions so subtly that you are taken by surprise and overwhelmed when those emotions come into play in the final act. When Frank and Bufalino go to prison, the film doesn't jump over their sentence, we stay with them. Scorsese knows that the real power of this story is to stay with Frank as an old man instead of using a montage or epilogue cards. This biopic of Frank Sheeren is a sad, tragic movie, but it is so well executed cinematically and emotionally that it is a joy to watch. I was reminded of a quote from the great critic Roger Ebert, "No great movie is depressing. All bad movies are depressing"

Joe Pesci was sooo good as Russell.  Another character with seemingly opposite sides to him as he genuinely looked after and supported Frank but was also this merciless guy who had to make really difficult choices in his relationships.

Jimmy Hoffa, perfectly played by Al Pacino...made it clear why Jimmy Hoffa was such a hated figure.  I did not like this guy I enjoyed getting a history lesson on the Teamsters and who Hoffa was.

I know people don't believe this Frank's account of what happened to Jimmy Hoffa, but it does make sense as to why he's never been found. Cremation will definitely remove the evidence.

Special effects were surprising but I really loved seeing these older actors get to play themselves younger.  I'm so used to seeing people get made up to look older that this was a welcome change.

I strongly recommend seeing this move.  The time flew by and I was completely caught up in the story and reminded why Deniro, Pacino and Pesci are such friggin' awesome actors.
The extreme runtime is soothed by the slow burn of this story coming together. Must watch for the actors alone.The slightly plodding second act is justified by an impactful climax.

It's a masterpiece. Be prepared to watch a long, epic, enjoyable masterpiece.

By now, anyone choosing to go and watch The Irishman knows that it's long. And that's probably a good thing: the viewer knows to prepare themselves. The run-time stands at an intimidating three-and-a-half hours. It's good news, then, that Robert De Niro himself has said it's acceptable to watch the film in several goes. It's not that the film doesn't feel long - it does, and the first half is particularly challenging to endure - but almost every minute on screen feels warranted, necessary even. 

It's challenging for many reasons, not just the film's length. For one, there are so many characters it's hard to keep track of the names, actions, and motives of each.  Another difficulty I had is deciphering the particularly thick and deep accents. But, despite all my hang up about Netflix's role in cinema, watching it there gave me the ability to pause and rewind when I needed to. The Irishman is unquestionably epic. It spans five decades, from the '50s to the early '00s. Much has been discussed of the incredible youthification technology which de-ages the lead actors. It's so good, in fact, that the viewer pretty much forgets about it entirely. That's even more remarkable considering the fact that De Niro, Pesci, and Pacino are A-list celebrities, faces we've seen and continue to see on a regular basis. But it isn't just the technology that engenders the de-aging effect, it's also the skill of the actors, who alter their posture, gait, and mannerisms to convincing effect. 

All three aforementioned actors are stellar. De Niro gives a solid performance and is likely (and probably rightly) upset about his not being nominated for Best Actor at the Oscars. Pesci and Pacino are both nominated for Supporting Actor, and both are superb. But it's Pesci who really shines in his role. Whether in acclaimed gangster classic Goodfellas or family favourite Home Alone, we're used to seeing him as an animatedly loathsome criminal, uncouth and loud. But in The Irishman Pesci is different, delivering a career-best performance: quietly sinister, alternating between providing counsel and instructions to kill with frightening indifference. Thank god that Scorsese finally convinced him to come out of (an almost ten year) retirement to make this movie. 

Scorsese's film is at its zenith is when it's showing us the aged mobsters struggling to make sense of their lives of unspeakable crime, now that death is at their doorstep. Frank Sheeran (De Niro's character) long ago lost the ability to feel remorse for his actions, probably way back in the war, before the film even starts; but as The Irishman reaches its conclusion, and Sheeran finds himself with no distraction and only the stretch of time before his eventual death, he finds himself reflecting on the life he's led. It's devastating and moving to see this man, once clinical and remorseless, grasping to come to terms with what he's done, and to cope with the guilt that he finally seems to feel. The final scenes between the vicar and Sheeran are my favourite in the film. 

An over-busy first half which perhaps lacks electricity transfigures into a strongly meaningful and thrilling second, before it finally opens up into a poignant and profound final act. The Irishman feels like Scorsese's swansong: a final ode to the gangster film.

Maybe it's because it's called The Irishman that I went in not expecting it to revolve entirely around Jimmy Hoffa until a wikipedia on the source material afterwards. (Who am I kidding, it was during).

Which brings me to the Title Card that flashes up: I Heard You Paint Houses, which at first I thought must have been a title card, but by the end I knew was Scorcese being subversive and subtle as usual, having his cake and eating it. I enjoyed that.

More subversion for me comes in the form of (eventually) Anna Paquin's daughter character. Much maligned recently for its lack of dialogue, I actually think the role has more presence than any of the other nonsense. Most dialogue is as sociopathic and soulless and workmanlike as the man himself, Jimmy a man broken and remade as a killer by the War, and so much of it is meaningless. Anna Paquin's stare, her broken accusatory look, pained but as if suppressing permanently, was actually very powerful, and to be able to link the child and adult actors wih the same feeling inside their characters is an inspired bit of casting and directing.

De Niro is stunning and every bit the actor throughout that he has been his whole life. Unlike Pacino who blossoms half way through, he's incredible from the start. His V/O is very very good (incidentally the device that makes it look like he's talking to no one is excessively effective and cheeky) and he manages to (unlike Joe Pesci) act young. With exception of the bit where he crushes the man's hand where he walks and moves like a 70-year-old man.

Which brings us to the CGI, undeniably groundbreaking, and sometimes effective to a wonderful degree, and other times completely jarring and awkward and pulls you straight out of the movie. The eyes feel wrong, almost throughout, too blue, too CGI and sometimes too doe-eyed and glasssy, and sometimes the lips are terrible. And that magic of having DeNiro play a young Brando in The Godfather has been completely removed, now a young actor can't prove his grit when an old actor can be rendered younger, it's a real shame, especially when the old can act young, but the young *are* young. That's a different spirit. But when it works it's seamless and often I couldn't tell when they were aged up or down and by how much.

Overall the film is quite good. That phone call scene is maybe the single best scene I've seen in a year, DeNiro is brilliant. The use of titles explaining the deaths of characters makes it more the special that in this film, Jimmy is still alive. It brings links between the Mafia and the Unions that I never knew, and the banality of some of these people and their lives mixed with the violence of their ends is effectively transmitted.

Also. Action Bronson is in it. The ending, regardless of the protracted runtime, is a riveting and subtle closing of the circle, the quietness of it struck me and stayed with me, an elegant master has created out of a handful of lines, how Jimmy sees himself and his end. To the Priest, and by proxy possibly to Saint Peter: "Don't shut the door all the way". Can an unrepentant man go to Heaven? Is Frank that man at all?

'The Irishman' (2019) - This is Scorsese in his mob-movie prime. Something I'll admit I never thought I would see again. Yes, the legendary director has had amazing films I've loved such as "The Departed", "Wolf of Wall Street", although I never thought I would see a film that took me back to the magic that is one of my favorite films of all time: "Goodfellas", his masterpiece in my opinion. Imagine "Goodfellas" but with a much older cast and mentality. Only Scorsese can direct a 3 hour and 30 minute movie and make it fly by so seamlessly. I was hooked from the beginning, and taken for a ride. No, it's not as high-octane of a ride as "Goodfellas" or "Wolf of Wall Street", and I'll do my best to lessen the comparisons to his other films, however this is a much more meditative approach to his style, themes of morality, death, and time passing by in the blink of an eye are recurring throughout. Each actor gives astounding performances, and what a legendary cast: Pacino, Pesci, De Niro, three presences I never thought to have seen on film at once. The gradual progression of the plot is also practically flawless, and the editing is simply phenomenal. Movies like this are scarce in the industry today, and only Martin can really craft these mob-epics to such a perfect degree. Regardless of it's lengthy run-time, it's a film I look forward to rewatching. Not as good as "Goodfellas", but this is certainly high-up in his filmography for me. If this were Scorsese's last film, it honestly would be a bang to go out with, and only strengthens the legendary director's legacy.

My review: The Irishman is part of a dead genre that no one cares about anymore. It has no social importance or, more seriously, redemption. It is a movie about white men killing white men. There are no women, no blacks, no other ethnicities but Italians (even the "Irishman" is played by an Italian). Movies like this have littered the film landscape for 38 years since 1972's The Godfather (which did the same thing but so much better, mainly because the genre was new). 
On a broader brush I say: Scorsese and Tarantino and the ilk should no longer have the power to make their pointless glorification of murder stories. It is long past time to let new voices with new visions into the boys club of directing and producing movies. I am a movie lover fed up with decades of stories about murderers. Make it stop. Find some better stories. And story tellers.

'The Irishman' is a 3 and a half hour epic based on the book 'I Heard You Paint Houses' by Charles Brandt, following the story of Frank Sheeran, initially a meat delivery driver, and eventually becoming Jimmy Hoffa's bodyguard, and looking at the lead up, and aftermath, of Jimmy Hoffa's disappearance. This film was directed by Martin Scorsese. The first concern of this film maybe that it's 3 and a half hours long. However, the direction and editing (by Thelma Schoonmaker), means that this film, which is dialogue heavy, feels like a 2 hour 45 minute film. Despite this, at some points within the dialogue heavy scenes it did feel to drag on, and about 15 to 20 minutes of the film could be cut to keep the pace up. Scorsese provides excellence once again within this movie, creating a 15 minute long sequence that keeps building up tension up to the climax of the sequence, one of the few film makers who can execute such a well crafted sequence. Written by Steven Zaillain, the screenplay for this film is excellent, the dialogue always felt like it was coming from the character and not a page, and the exclusion of Peggy Sheeran later in the film is a prime example of great show, don't tell storytelling. Edited by Thelma Schoonmaker and shot by Rodrigo Prieto, this film does an excellent job at always carrying a tension within a scene, with cuts never being too long or short. However,  at times within this film the continuity between shots didn't add up which momentarily took you out of the story. This film provided excellent all-round acting from the whole cast, especially from Robert De Niro (Frank Sheeran), Al Pacino (Jimmy Hoffa) and Joe Pesci (Russell Bufalino). This film is overall really well made with great direction, acting, editing and writing. Scorsese provides another incredible mob epic with a near unmatched ability to build tension within scenes.

Martin Scorsese's three and a half hour gangster epic, released by Netflix, feels like the culmination of his career. Based on the book "I Heard You Paint Houses" by Charles Brandt, adapted by Steven Zaillian, about a truck driver (Robert DeNiro) looking back on his time working as a hitman for a mobster (Joe Pesci), which leads to his employment as a bodyguard for Jimmy Hoffa (Al Pacino). In his seventies, Scorsese has made a drama about mortality and regret along with his usual themes of sin and redemption, but the youthful energy, black humor, and expressionism of his classics "Mean Streets" and GoodFellas" are missing, so our interest fades. This elegy to the mafia has similarities to Bergman's "Wild Strawberries." De Niro and Pacino give solid performances, but Pesci stands out. Known for his volatile, maniacal performances in previous Scorsese movies, Pesci shows a restraint here that is astonishing because he still maintains authority. A new technology used involving de aging effects is unconvincing. The actors are made to look younger facially, but the rest of their physical appearance has been unaltered. Another defect is the women in the movie are mostly nonexistent. Cinematography is by Rodrigo Prieto. Music is by Robbie Robertson. Editing is by Thelma Schoonmaker. With Harvey Keitel, Ray Romano, Bobby Canavale, Anna Paquin.

Any time a film directed by the great Martin Scorsese is released, the anticipation is high, and with good reason. With films like Taxi Driver, Goodfellas, Shutter Island and Casino credited to his name, the expectations for The Irisman were very high, and Scorsese delivers in spectacular fashion. In a film concerning the massive personality of Jimmy Hoffa ( played beautifully by Al Pacino ), Robert DeNiro gives a wonderfully subdued performance as Frank Sheeran, Hoffa's bodyguard and closest friend. In the moments that Pacino is on screen, he controls the mood effortlessly going from calm, cool and collected to raging mad and then back down again. But perhaps the unsung star of this film is the masterful portrayal of Russell Buffalino by Joe Pesci. Pesci's cold blooded performance is, in my opinion, the best by an actor in a supporting roll in 2019 bar none. 
 Not to be overlooked in this film is the beautiful cinematography, coupled with the groundbreaking de-aging software used to bring these characters to life. Something that was very refreshing to me was that this film allowed it's characters to just exist. Scorsese used the talent he knew these actors have to his full advantage. The dialogue in this film is near-perfect both from a writing perspective and from an acting perspective. Tension mounts in this film not by a sudden sound or some other common cheap trick used in many films today, but by a single phrase or facial expression which gives the viewer that sense of wondering just what is going to happen next. 
 The Irishman is without question a major contender for the best picture award at the Academy Awards this year competing only, in my opinion, with Joker and Marriage Story. This film is a fresh reminder to Hollywood that it is okay to just let your script develope and breathe and to not congest a film with unnecessary CGI and explosions.

Personally, my favourite cast of the year besides 'Knives Out' as well.

At this stage in his career, Martin Scorsese could make any film he wanted and, regardless of quality, it would be heaped with praise and called a masterpiece. The Irishman is a prime example of that. It feels likes the Director's swansong, a movie that crams in everything he's become known for over the decades, casts some of his favourite actors, and voila, cinematic magic. At 3 and a half hours long, the movie is unforgivably overextended. Like Wolf Of Wall Street, the first hour was enjoyable, but things drag more and more the longer it goes on. So many things feel manufactured to amp up the runtime. Establishing shots take too long, conversations are rambling, some scenes are pointless, there's way too many characters and all the major ones get a narrated introduction. If its intention was to make us sympathise with Jiffy Hoffa then it fails, since Pacino is essentially recycling his ‘Guy who argues at length with everybody' schtick, and it gets so annoying that you actively want him to die. The acting is good, as you'd imagine from the cast it has, but nobody is doing anything especially noteworthy. DeNiro is doing his ‘DeNiro in a mobster movie' performance, which he's done plenty of times before, and Harvey Keitel has so little screen time that I don't know what we would lose if his character was completely cut. Anna Paquin, an Oscar winner let's not forget, has about 4 lines of dialogue, and spends most of the film staring in disbelief, something that I'm pretty sure any actress could have pulled off. At the end of the day, The Irishman will be praised as a modern classic, but when stacked up with movies like Goodfellas, Raging Bull & Taxi Driver, it will not be recognised as one of Scorsese's finest, only the longest.

It was only after watching The Irishman that I looked up the details and found that it is based on factual events (although the story as portrayed in the movie is highly disputed). To get De Niro, Pacino together again is an utter joy. Adding in Joe Pesci is a cherry on top. This fantastic movie from director Martin Scorsese sees the trio return to themes that have featured large in all of their careers telling as it does a story of Mafia, mobsters and hitmen spanning a period of many decades. The Irishman of the title is a young truck driver, Frank Sheeran (De Niro), who earns a bit on the side by cutting deals and swindling his employer while delivering meat. Through his wheeler-dealing he crosses paths with Russ Bufalino (Pesci) who heads a family with deep connections to the mob. Sheeran begins to work for Bufalino and starts to gain a reputation as a trustworthy strong arm guy and hitman. This in turn leads him to develop links with union boss Jimmy Hoffa (Pacino).
The story weaves a slow and complicated path where the friendship, rivalry and power play between the three is superbly observed. Each has a very different character with Hoffa mercurial and obsessive, Sheeran quiet, loyal and ruthless and Bufalino calculating and diplomatic. The whole movie is a fascinating character study and the interplay between the three leads is electrifying. These are truly actors at the top of their game.
The technical innovation f this movie is the way in which all three actors are made to appear younger by several decades from their actual age. I the past, this would have been achieved by employing different actors to play the men at different ages or by employing younger actors and ageing them with make-up. Here, Scorsese in his own words uses digital technology "As make-up" and it really does work. At first, I wasn't too sure as De Niro's face is so well known these days from his older roles and it is a real shock to see him unexpectedly young. However, the initial uncertainty is soon forgotten and the fact that all three age progressively as we pass through the years seems natural and very effective. 
It is a long movie at over three hours but, unlike many films that have similar runtimes, there is not a minute that feels like padding and I was totally absorbed by the on-screen action. What Scorsese does so well here is tell a story of relationship. It is about family and friendship, betrayal and tragedy. Beautifully shot, wonderfully acted and expertly paced this is a truly brilliant picture.

Martin Scorcese's latest film, based (probably loosely) on the life of Frank Sheehan (played by Robert DeNiro), an associate of the mob and of Jimmy Hoffa, is very impressive. There are two narrative strands that weave to form the overall story and narrated by Frank Sheehan in the present from his nursing home: The road trip that was taken by him and his mob boss Russell Buffalino (Joe Pesci) to attend a wedding and meet with Jimmy Hoffa (Al Pacino) and the story of how Sheehan rose in the ranks as he did. The acting overall is great, but the performances by DeNiro, Pesci, and Pacino are brilliant – the choice to cast these three, veterans from previous mob films and Scorcese films was excellent. They all do a great job of playing younger and older versions of themselves. DeNiro and Pesci are especially great – both disappear into their roles and give their characters deep believability. Even though I think some parts of the story were created for dramatic effect, the overall story, at its 3.5-hour length (I had to watch it in two sittings), is well shot and scripted for a very compelling story; I could not figure out what I would cut if I could. The capturing of the period through the music and cinematography are also excellent, even down to the wives who were constantly demanding their husbands take cigarette breaks while on their drive to Detroit – those hairdos and Virginia Slims! And, thanks to this film, I now know what it means to "paint houses and do my own construction". Big thumbs up from me for an impressive achievement in storytelling and character development.

I wanted to love this film. But, really, it's just bad. These are older actors, Pacino, DeNiro, Pesci. That, in and of itself, is not problematic. I'm older, so older can be pretty damn attractive. But, the attempt to represent youthful vigor through the use of older actors simply didn't work. CGI can't create the intensity of the palpable energy that DeNiro and Pacino generated on screen, two generations ago. The "young" CGI characters lacked their vitality, because it wasn't there in the actors, themselves anymore. Also, their CGI faces were eerily off-putting at times.  And, occasionally, it looked as though DeNiro was wearing a hint of blue shadow on his eyelids due to the CGI bluing of his eyes. Overall, the film and its characters felt plodding and predictable. I n addition, I prefer my long-held belief that Jimmy was weighted down in a Jersey Pine Barrens' lake where my kids used to rent paddle boats as a better answer to his whereabouts, IF we should have gotten one at all. Worst of all, it took 3.5 hours to find out that I didn't care about the characters played by some of my most admired actors, and I wished they hadn't done it. If this wins awards, it will be like a participation trophy. So, I'm hoping that doesn't happen, either.

Review: 
‘The Irishman' is a crime film directed by Martin Scorsese. It is based on the book ‘I Heard You Paint Houses' by Charles Brandt.
Martin Scorsese comes back to gangster films and brings the big bosses from the genre with him. This movie is a three and a half hour long epic and while it doesn't necessary fly by, you enjoy every minute.
The film follows Frank Sheeran (Robert De Niro), a truck driver who becomes a hitman involved with mobster Russell Bufalino (Joe Pesci) and his crime family, including his time working for the powerful Teamster Jimmy Hoffa (Al Pacino).
The powerhouse of actors in this movie is what sold me on it, aside form it being a Martin Scorsese film. I'm not going to talk a lot about the acting in this movie, we all know who these people are and wat they are capable of and with an amazing director behind them, no wrong can be done. I do want to discuss one actor that when a lot of people think of him, they think of Home Alone, and that's Joe Pesci. He was amazing in this movie. He stole every scene he was in for me and I was in awe watching his performance. 
It's not a flawless movie and I wouldn't necessarily call it a masterpiece or something new and innovative. But for an old genre gangster film it's easily one of the best ones out there on recent years. It does have a long runtime and it is an investment, but the story being told is very good.
Overall, the movie has great performances with a very good story. The runtime is long, but if you can be invested in the story that's being told it won't matter. I really enjoyed thee film and think people who liked film such as ‘Casino' or ‘Goodfellas' will enjoy this movie too.
